column1: Silverdale is a census-designated place (CDP) in Kitsap County
column3: in the United States. The population was 19
column4: 204 at the 2010 census. Despite many attempts at incorporation
column5: Silverdale remains an unincorporated community.Silverdale ranks 158th among 522 areas in Washington for which per capita income data is collected.

column1: Silverdale is located on the Kitsap Peninsula at 47°39′34″N 122°40′36″W (47.659410
column2: -122.676630). It is 9 miles (14 km) northwest of the city of Bremerton and the same distance south of Poulsbo. Silverdale lies at the north tip of Dyes Inlet
column3: which connects it to Bremerton via Sinclair Inlet and to the Pacific Ocean via Port Orchard and Puget Sound.

column1: Commerce in Silverdale is primarily divided into two geographic areas: Old Town Silverdale along the northeast edge of Dyes Inlet
column2: and the Kitsap Mall and big box stores (Costco Wholesale Center

column1: A branch of Harrison Medical Center opened on Myhre Road in 2000. Harrison Silverdale will be expanded and the Harrison Bremerton campus closed.
Central Kitsap School District serves about 11
column2: 000 students from kindergarten through grade 12. The district has two high schools serving grades 9 to 12
column3: one secondary school serving grades 7 to 12
column4: three middle schools serving grades six to eight
column7: and a home-school support program.  In addition
column8: the district offers both junior high- and high school-level alternative programs. The overall graduation rate as of 2010 is 89.4% which is well above the statewide rate of 72%.On September 8
column10: construction began on the new Central Kitsap Campus which will house Central Kitsap High School and Central Kitsap Middle School. The current buildings were built in 1942 and 1959 respectively.  It is expected that middle school students will be able to move into the new building in Spring 2019 while high school students will move in Fall 2019.  Construction for the new campus was contracted through Skanksa for $77.9 million.  Central Kitsap School District sold the naming rights to the new campus' stadium to Kitsap Credit Union for $500
column11: 000.  The stadium will be named "Kitsap Credit Union Athletic Complex."
